original_title: Sri Lanka private credit positive in Oct, Sept CB credit revised down
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s private credit expanded 37.9 billion rupees to 7,206 billion rupees in October 2023, while credit to government from banks fell, official data shows.
Central Bank credit numbers in the previous months were sharply revised down to 2,424 billion rupees from 2,841 billion rupees.
In September the central bank was hit by large losses, from a domestic debt restructure and the IMF has urged a re-capitalization plan.
Credit to state enterprises went up slightly to 1,109.8 billion rupees from 1,098 billion rupees.
Private credit was positive for the third fight straight month.
Sri Lanka’s private credit contracted in 2023, after rate were hiked to stop a currency crisis, triggered by previous rate cuts.
When private credit picks up, and there may be short term pressure on government securities yields even if the budget deficit falls.
In the past the central bank has then tended to print money, through open market operations, converting bank held Treasuries into reserve money, and trigger external instability. (Colombo/Dec18/2023)
